clinical_study.brief_title: Open Facet Joint Denervation in the Treatment of Low Back Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Open Facet Joint Denervation in the Treatment of Low Back Pain -A Randomized Control Trial.

brief_summary.textblock: A single blinded RCT for adult patients with spine pain. One group had a lumbar laminectomy with denervation of the facet joint at the level decompressed. The other group had a lumbar laminectomy without facet joint denervation. Both groups had their back pain and functional limitations measured using a 10 cm visual analogue scale and the Oswestry disability index (ODI). All measures were taken before surgery and at patients' 6, 12 and 24 week follow-up clinic visit.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Visual analog scale for pain (VAS)
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline score at 24 weeks
primary_outcome.description: 10 centimeter scale with a minimum of 0 indicating no pain and a maximum of 10 indicating worst pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Modified Oswestry Disability score (ODI)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline score at 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The ODI is divided into ten sections designed to assess limitations of various activities of daily living. Each section is scored on a 0-5 scale. The range of scores is 0 to a maximum of 60. The total score is multiplied by 2 and expressed as a percentage. A score of 0 to 20 points indicates minimal disability; 20 to 40 points, moderate disability; and 40 to 60 points, severe disability.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged 19 or older
- a diagnosis of spinal stenosis
- having neurogenic claudication
- complained of back pain for at least 3 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous surgery on their spine,
- fracture, systemic inflammatory disease,
- malignancies or an infection affecting their spine
